Award.AwardTitle: Catch and Release of Small Molecules With Porous Nanocapsules
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to control the transport of small molecules through very small pores in membranes is important for a variety of applications such as the development of drug delivery systems and separation techniques. An improved understanding of the fundamental chemistry that controls the transport of small molecules would have broad biomedical, biotechnology, and environmental implications.

The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program supports the work of Professor Eugene Pinkhassik of the University of Connecticut focusing on regulating the transport of small molecules through gated nanopores and creating nanocapsules capable of rapid uptake and release of small molecules. The transport will be regulated by controlling the chemical environment of nanopores and by reversible binding of plugs or lids. This interdisciplinary project integrates research and training with outreach activities aimed at underrepresented groups in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Regulation of transport through nanometer-thin shells of hollow polymer nanocapsules is the key to creating functional nanoscale devices, such as vehicles for the delivery of drugs and imaging agents. This project focused on investigating new motifs for the controlled permeability of the shells and achieving selective uptake and release of molecules using nanocapsules. Other goals included development of simple, cheap, and scalable methods for the synthesis of nanocapsules and exploring the application of nanocapsules enabled by controlled permeability of shells.

Intellectual Merit

We demonstrated two motifs for the uptake and release of molecules using porous hollow nanocapsules. One method is based on regulating the transport through the shells in response to the pH of the environment. The rationale for this work was the desire to take advantage of different physiological pH values. For example, blood is slightly basic while the interior of endosomes, tumors, and tissue at early stages of wound healing are mildly acidic. In our approach, the pores in the shells of nanocapsules are decorated with carboxylic groups, which makes them deprotonated and negatively charged in neutral and basic pH and protonated and electroneutral in acidic conditions. As a result, negatively charged molecules pass through the pores in when the capsule is places in acidic environment and do not pass in neutral or basic environment. This pH-mediated regulation of transport can be used for the carrying the molecules within the capsules in the bloodstream and releasing them in acidic conditions.

Another motif for capture and release of molecules is based on change in effective size of molecules due to non-covalent interactions. A conformationally flexible molecule enters nanocapsules through the pores. A non-covalent complex formation inside the nanocapsule increases the effective size of the molecule preventing it from escaping from the capsule. Then, an externally triggered breaks up the complex, allowing the release of the components of the complex.

Selective permeability of the shells enabled diverse applications of nanocapsules. In this project, we explored the feasibility of creating nanosensors and nanoreactors. We showed that entrapment of indicator dyes in nanocapsules formed a series of optical nanosensors, which could be immobilized in highly permeable matrices, e.g., hydrogels. These sensors revealed a combination of fast response times with reproducible performance and lack of leaching of indicator dyes. Entrapment of gold or silver nanoparticles formed selective nanoprobes for surface-enhanced raman scattering (SERS). Due to controlled permeability of the shells, these nanoprobes were capable of the selective detection of target analytes from in complex mixtures, such as blood plasma. Likewise, selective permeability enabled the creation of nanoreactors containing encapsulated homogeneous or nanoparticle catalysts that retained the catalysts while permitting unhindered flow of substrates and products. We showed that entrapment of catalysts did not compromise the catalytic efficiency of reactions. Size-selective permeability resulted in selective catalytic reactions based on the size of substrates.

Other aspects of selective permeability through the nanopores permitted the assembly of hybrid nanostructures, such as ship-in-a-bottle assembly of nanorattles containing either large molecules assembled from small components or selectively grown metal nanoparticles.

The studies mentioned above were made possible by the development of robust and scalable synthetic methods for the assembly of nanocapsules. In particular, during this project, we reported a simple an inexpensive synthesis of nanopcapsules using surfactant scaffolds and assembly of nanocapsules under physiological conditions. Synthetic work was supported by detailed studies of monomer-surfactant aggregates leading to the nanocapsule synthesis with multiple methods, including neutron scattering. For example, neutron studies were critical in establishing synergistic self-assembly of monomers and surfactants into monomer-loaded vesicles.

Broader Impacts

This project has laid the foundation for technologies beneficial to society, such as devices for the delivery of drugs and imaging agents, fast-acting and selective nanoreactors, and optical and SERS nanoprobes.

This project supported professional development of multiple graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows, including students from underrepresented groups.

Outreach activities involved hundreds of pre-college students, including more than twenty students who were involved in hands-on experience in the research laboratory.
